questions.question: Under IRC Section 61, gross income includes:

options.A: Only income from employment
options.B: All income from whatever source derived unless specifically excluded
options.C: Only income reported on Form W-2
options.D: Only income earned within the United States

questions.explanation: IRC Section 61 defines gross income broadly as all income from whatever source derived, unless specifically excluded by another provision of the tax code. This includes wages, business income, investment income, and all other income regardless of form or source.
questions.tip: Gross income = everything unless the code says it's excluded.

questions.question: Which of the following is included in an employee's gross income?

options.A: Employer-paid health insurance premiums
options.B: Cash wages and tips
options.C: Employer contributions to a qualified pension plan
options.D: Group term life insurance coverage up to $50,000

questions.explanation: Cash wages and tips are fully includible in gross income. Employer-paid health insurance premiums, pension contributions, and the first $50,000 of group term life insurance coverage are excluded from the employee's gross income under specific code sections.
questions.tip: Cash = taxable. Most employer benefits have specific exclusions.

questions.question: Interest on U.S. savings bonds is:

options.A: Tax-exempt at the federal level
options.B: Taxable for federal income tax purposes
options.C: Tax-exempt at the state level only
options.D: Never taxable

questions.explanation: Interest on U.S. savings bonds (Series EE, I bonds) is taxable for federal income tax purposes but exempt from state and local taxes. This differs from municipal bonds, which are generally exempt from federal tax.
questions.tip: Federal bonds = taxable for federal, exempt from state. Municipal bonds = opposite.

questions.question: A gift received from a friend is:

options.A: Included in gross income of the recipient
options.B: Excluded from the recipient's gross income
options.D: Included in income only if from a relative

questions.explanation: Under IRC Section 102, the value of property acquired by gift, bequest, devise, or inheritance is excluded from the recipient's gross income. The gift tax, if any, is paid by the donor, not the recipient.
questions.tip: Gifts are excluded from the recipient's income—donor may owe gift tax.

questions.question: Life insurance proceeds received by a beneficiary due to the death of the insured are generally:

options.A: Fully taxable as ordinary income
options.B: Excluded from gross income
options.D: Taxable only to the extent they exceed premiums paid

questions.explanation: Under IRC Section 101(a), life insurance proceeds paid by reason of the death of the insured are excluded from the beneficiary's gross income. This exclusion applies regardless of the amount and whether the policy was term or whole life.
questions.tip: Death benefit life insurance = tax-free to beneficiary.

questions.question: Interest received on bonds issued by a state or local government is:

options.A: Taxable at both federal and state levels
options.B: Excluded from gross income for federal tax purposes
options.C: Taxable at the federal level only
options.D: Taxable only if the bondholder itemizes deductions

questions.explanation: Interest on state and local government bonds (municipal bonds) is generally excluded from federal gross income under IRC Section 103. However, some municipal bonds (private activity bonds) may be subject to the alternative minimum tax.
questions.tip: Muni bond interest = federal tax-free (but may affect AMT).

questions.question: Qualified dividends are taxed at:

options.A: Ordinary income rates
options.B: Preferential rates of 0%, 15%, or 20% depending on taxable income
options.D: Self-employment tax rates

questions.explanation: Qualified dividends are taxed at preferential long-term capital gains rates of 0%, 15%, or 20% based on the taxpayer's taxable income level. To be qualified, dividends must be from domestic corporations or qualified foreign corporations and meet holding period requirements.
questions.tip: Qualified dividends = same rate as LTCG (0%, 15%, or 20%).

questions.question: For divorce agreements executed after December 31, 2018, alimony payments are:

options.A: Deductible by the payor and taxable to the recipient
options.B: Not deductible by the payor and not taxable to the recipient
options.D: Subject to capital gains rates

questions.explanation: The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act changed the treatment of alimony for agreements executed after 2018. Alimony is no longer deductible by the payor and is not included in the recipient's gross income. This reverses the prior treatment.
questions.tip: Post-2018 divorce: alimony is neither deductible nor taxable (no tax effect).

questions.question: When a debt is canceled, the debtor generally must:

options.A: Report the canceled amount as income
options.B: Report it as a capital gain
options.C: Reduce basis in property by the canceled amount
options.D: Ignore it if under $600

questions.explanation: Under IRC Section 61(a)(12), income from the cancellation of debt is included in gross income. Exceptions exist for bankruptcy, insolvency, qualified principal residence indebtedness (for certain years), and qualified farm or business real property debt.
questions.tip: Debt forgiveness = taxable income unless an exception applies (bankruptcy, insolvency).

questions.question: A taxpayer who wins $5,000 in a lottery must:

options.A: Include it in gross income only if over $10,000
options.B: Report the full amount as ordinary income
options.D: Report it as capital gain

questions.explanation: Prizes and awards, including lottery winnings, are fully includible in gross income as ordinary income under IRC Section 74. There is no de minimis exception. Gambling winnings are reported on Schedule 1 of Form 1040.
questions.tip: Lottery/gambling winnings = fully taxable ordinary income.

questions.question: Social Security benefits may be included in gross income:

options.A: Never, they are always tax-free
options.B: Up to 50% or 85% depending on provisional income
options.C: At 100% if the taxpayer is still working
options.D: Only for taxpayers over age 70

questions.explanation: Social Security benefits are taxed based on provisional income (modified AGI plus 50% of benefits). If provisional income exceeds certain thresholds, up to 50% or 85% of benefits become taxable. The maximum taxable portion is 85%.
questions.tip: Social Security taxability: 0%, 50%, or 85% based on provisional income thresholds.

questions.question: Unemployment compensation received by a taxpayer is:

options.A: Excluded from gross income
options.B: Fully includible in gross income
options.C: Taxable only at the state level
options.D: Taxable only if the taxpayer has other income

questions.explanation: Unemployment compensation is fully taxable and included in gross income under IRC Section 85. Recipients receive Form 1099-G reporting the total amount paid during the year. Taxpayers can elect to have federal income tax withheld from benefits.
questions.tip: Unemployment benefits = fully taxable (no exclusion).

questions.question: Worker's compensation payments received for a job-related injury are:

options.A: Fully taxable
options.B: Excluded from gross income
options.D: Taxable only if over the employee's basis

questions.explanation: Worker's compensation payments received for personal physical injuries or sickness arising out of employment are excluded from gross income under IRC Section 104(a)(1). This includes both periodic payments and lump-sum settlements.
questions.tip: Worker's comp = tax-free (for physical injury/sickness).

questions.question: A scholarship used to pay for tuition and required fees at a qualified educational institution is:

options.A: Fully taxable
options.B: Excluded from gross income if the student is a degree candidate
options.D: Deductible by the donor only

questions.explanation: Under IRC Section 117, qualified scholarships used for tuition and required fees, books, supplies, and equipment are excluded from gross income for degree-seeking students. Amounts used for room, board, or other expenses are taxable.
questions.tip: Scholarship for tuition/fees = tax-free. Room and board = taxable.

questions.question: Under the constructive receipt doctrine, income is taxable when:

options.A: The taxpayer actually receives the cash
options.B: The income is credited, set apart, or made available without substantial limitations
options.D: The payor issues a 1099

questions.explanation: Constructive receipt means income is taxable when it is credited to the taxpayer's account, set apart for them, or made available so they can draw upon it—even if not actually received. The taxpayer cannot turn their back on available income.
questions.tip: Constructive receipt = income available without restriction, even if not taken.

questions.question: Advance rent received by a landlord is:

options.A: Taxable in the year received regardless of the period covered
options.B: Taxable over the rental period
options.D: Deferred until the tenant moves out

questions.explanation: Under the cash method, advance rent is taxable in the year received regardless of the period covered. Even accrual-method taxpayers must include advance rent in income when received because there is no fixed obligation to return it.
questions.tip: Advance rent = taxable when received (no deferral allowed).

questions.question: Which of the following fringe benefits is excluded from an employee's gross income?

options.A: Personal use of company car
options.B: Qualified employee discount on employer's merchandise
options.D: Cash bonus for exceeding sales targets

questions.explanation: Qualified employee discounts on employer merchandise (up to gross profit percentage) or services (up to 20%) are excluded from gross income under IRC Section 132. Personal use of company cars, club memberships for personal purposes, and cash bonuses are taxable.
questions.tip: Employee discounts = excluded up to limits. Cash/personal perks = taxable.

questions.question: De minimis fringe benefits are excluded from income because:

options.A: They are specifically listed in the tax code
options.B: Their value is so small that accounting for them would be unreasonable or impractical
options.D: They are provided to all employees equally

questions.explanation: De minimis fringe benefits are excluded because their value is so small that accounting for them would be unreasonable or administratively impractical. Examples include occasional personal use of copy machine, coffee, holiday parties, and small gifts.
questions.tip: De minimis = too small to track (occasional coffee, parties, small gifts).

questions.question: Employer-provided group term life insurance coverage is excluded from an employee's gross income:

options.A: For all coverage amounts
options.B: For coverage up to $50,000
options.C: Only if the employee pays the premiums
options.D: Only for coverage purchased outside the workplace

questions.explanation: Under IRC Section 79, employer-paid premiums for group term life insurance are excluded from the employee's income for coverage up to $50,000. The cost of coverage exceeding $50,000 (determined by IRS tables) is included in income.
questions.tip: $50,000 group life = excluded. Excess coverage = taxable (using IRS Table I costs).

questions.question: The exclusion ratio for an annuity determines:

options.A: The amount of annual payments subject to penalty
options.B: The portion of each payment that is a tax-free return of investment
options.C: The total amount the annuitant will receive
options.D: The interest rate paid on the annuity

questions.explanation: The exclusion ratio (investment in contract ÷ expected return) determines what portion of each annuity payment is a tax-free return of the taxpayer's investment (basis). The remaining portion is taxable as ordinary income.
questions.tip: Exclusion ratio = investment ÷ expected return. That % of each payment is tax-free.

questions.question: Qualified distributions from a Roth IRA are:

options.A: Fully taxable as ordinary income
options.B: Tax-free if made after age 59½ and the account has been open for at least 5 years
options.D: Subject to a 10% early distribution penalty

questions.explanation: Qualified distributions from Roth IRAs are completely tax-free if made after age 59½ (or due to death, disability, or first home purchase) and the 5-year holding period is met. Contributions to Roth IRAs are made with after-tax dollars.
questions.tip: Roth = after-tax in, tax-free out (if qualified: 59½ + 5 years).

questions.question: Damages received in a lawsuit are excluded from gross income if they are:

options.A: For any personal injury
options.B: Received on account of personal physical injuries or physical sickness
options.D: Received as punitive damages

questions.explanation: Under IRC Section 104(a)(2), damages received on account of personal physical injuries or physical sickness are excluded from income. Damages for emotional distress (without physical injury), lost wages, or punitive damages are taxable.
questions.tip: Physical injury damages = tax-free. Emotional-only or punitive = taxable.

questions.question: Under the assignment of income doctrine:

options.A: A taxpayer can avoid tax by assigning income to a family member
options.B: Income is taxed to the person who earns it, regardless of who receives it
options.C: All family members share the tax burden equally
options.D: Income can be shifted to lower tax brackets

questions.explanation: The assignment of income doctrine prevents taxpayers from shifting income to lower-bracket family members. Income from services is taxed to the person who earns it, and income from property is taxed to the owner of the property.
questions.tip: You can't escape tax by giving away income—taxed to who earned it.

questions.question: A below-market loan from an employer to an employee results in:

options.A: No tax consequences
options.B: Imputed interest income to the employer and compensation income to the employee
options.D: A deduction for the employer only

questions.explanation: Below-market loans between employer and employee are recharacterized: the forgone interest is treated as a payment from lender to borrower (compensation to employee) and a payment back from borrower to lender (interest income to employer). The employee has W-2 income.
questions.tip: Below-market employer loans = imputed compensation to employee + interest to employer.

questions.question: Original issue discount (OID) on a bond is:

options.A: Taxed only when the bond is sold or matures
options.B: Included in income annually over the life of the bond
options.D: Taxed at capital gains rates

questions.explanation: Original issue discount (the excess of stated redemption price over issue price) must be included in income annually over the life of the bond using the constant yield method. This applies even though no cash is received until maturity.
questions.tip: OID = phantom income—taxed annually even without cash receipt.

questions.question: Interest on Series EE savings bonds may be excluded from income if:

options.A: The bonds are held for more than 5 years
options.B: Proceeds are used for qualified higher education expenses and income limits are met
options.C: The taxpayer is a full-time student
options.D: The bonds were purchased before age 18

questions.explanation: Under IRC Section 135, interest on Series EE and I bonds may be excluded if proceeds are used for qualified higher education expenses (tuition and fees) for the taxpayer, spouse, or dependents. Income phase-outs apply, and the bond owner must be at least 24 when issued.
questions.tip: EE bond interest exclusion: education expenses + income limits + age 24+ at purchase.

questions.question: Under the tax benefit rule, a taxpayer must include in income:

options.A: Any recovery of an amount previously deducted that provided a tax benefit
options.B: All refunds received
options.D: Amounts paid for medical expenses

questions.explanation: The tax benefit rule requires a taxpayer to include in income any recovery of an amount previously deducted if the deduction provided a tax benefit. If the prior deduction did not reduce tax (e.g., due to using standard deduction), the recovery may not be taxable.
questions.tip: Got a deduction? If you get it back, it's taxable (to the extent of tax benefit).

questions.question: Under the claim of right doctrine:

options.A: Income is only taxable when the taxpayer's right to it becomes absolute
options.B: Amounts received under a claim of right are included in income in the year received even if there is an obligation to repay
options.D: Income is deferred until legal disputes are resolved

questions.explanation: The claim of right doctrine requires taxpayers to include in income amounts received under a claim of right (unrestricted use), even if there is an obligation to repay in the future. If repayment is required later, a deduction or credit is available in the year of repayment.
questions.tip: Claim of right = include when received; get deduction if repaid later.

questions.question: The economic benefit doctrine provides that:

options.A: Income is taxable only when cash is received
options.B: A taxpayer realizes income when receiving an economic benefit, even if payment is deferred
options.C: All non-cash benefits are excluded from income
options.D: Economic benefits are always valued at cost to the provider

questions.explanation: Under the economic benefit doctrine, if a taxpayer receives an economic benefit (such as property set aside in a trust) with no substantial risk of forfeiture, income is recognized even without actual cash receipt. This prevents deferral through funded arrangements.
questions.tip: Economic benefit = if it's set aside for you without risk, it's taxable now.

questions.question: A U.S. citizen working abroad may exclude foreign earned income if:

options.A: They are present in the foreign country for any period
options.B: They meet the bona fide residence or physical presence test and have a tax home in a foreign country
options.C: Their employer is a foreign company
options.D: They pay foreign income taxes

questions.explanation: Under IRC Section 911, U.S. citizens and residents may exclude up to $120,000 (2023, indexed) of foreign earned income if they meet either the bona fide residence test or physical presence test (330 days in 12-month period) AND have a tax home in a foreign country.
questions.tip: Foreign income exclusion = foreign tax home + either bona fide residence or 330-day test.

questions.question: Student loan forgiveness under an income-driven repayment plan is generally:

options.A: Always excluded from income
options.B: Taxable as ordinary income (with some exceptions)
options.D: Excluded if the student is employed

questions.explanation: Student loan forgiveness is generally taxable as cancellation of debt income. However, loans forgiven under Public Service Loan Forgiveness or for death/disability are excluded. The American Rescue Plan Act temporarily excluded all student loan forgiveness through 2025.
questions.tip: Student loan forgiveness = usually taxable (but PSLF and some others excluded).

questions.question: When an employee purchases property from an employer for less than fair market value, the employee:

options.A: Has no taxable income
options.B: Must include the bargain element as compensation income
options.C: Reports capital gain equal to the discount
options.D: Can defer the income until the property is sold

questions.explanation: When an employee purchases property from an employer for less than FMV, the difference (bargain element) is compensation income. Exceptions exist for qualified employee discounts on inventory items (up to employer's gross profit percentage).
questions.tip: Bargain purchase from employer = taxable compensation (FMV - price paid).

questions.question: The 3.8% net investment income tax applies to:

options.A: All investment income regardless of AGI
options.B: Net investment income for taxpayers with modified AGI exceeding threshold amounts
options.D: Self-employment income

questions.explanation: The 3.8% net investment income tax (NIIT) applies to the lesser of net investment income or modified AGI exceeding thresholds ($250,000 MFJ, $200,000 single). Net investment income includes interest, dividends, capital gains, rents, royalties, and passive business income.
questions.tip: NIIT: 3.8% on investment income if MAGI exceeds $250K MFJ / $200K single.

questions.question: Under a cafeteria plan (Section 125), an employee who chooses qualified benefits:

options.A: Must include all benefits in income
options.B: Excludes the value of qualified benefits from income
options.C: Is taxed on the cash equivalent value
options.D: Must include benefits exceeding $5,000

questions.explanation: A cafeteria plan allows employees to choose between cash and qualified benefits. If the employee chooses qualified benefits (health insurance, FSA, etc.), those benefits are excluded from income. If cash is chosen, it's taxable. The choice doesn't trigger constructive receipt.
questions.tip: Cafeteria plan = choose benefits tax-free or cash taxable. No constructive receipt.

questions.question: Capital gains invested in a Qualified Opportunity Zone Fund:

options.A: Are permanently excluded from income
options.B: Are deferred until the earlier of sale of the investment or December 31, 2026
options.D: Are taxed immediately at reduced rates

questions.explanation: Capital gains invested in QOZ Funds are deferred until the earlier of the date the investment is sold or December 31, 2026. If held 10+ years, post-investment appreciation may be permanently excluded. The original gain is eventually recognized.
questions.tip: QOZ: defer gain until sale or 2026; 10+ years = exclude appreciation on QOZ investment.
